VB’s OrElse (AndAlso) revisited

Posted by stevehebert on April 25, 2006

After reading Billy Hollis’ explanation of Visual Basic’s OrElse and AndAlso statements,  I think it actually made me think less of VB. 

I vaguely remember studying these for the Microsoft VB5 certification test 8 or 9 years ago.  This is why the following statement doesn’t short circuit and causes a runtime error if Value[index] == null:

if Value[index] Is Not Null and Value[index] = “1″ then …

Instead you have to write it as:

if Value[index] Is Not Null AndAlso Value[Index] = “1″ then…

AndAlso??? AndAlso!?!? How could you implement those keywords without laughing the entire time you’re doing it?

This entry was posted in Uncategorized. Bookmark the permalink. Follow any comments here with the RSS feed for this post.

  1. Karl Anderson says:
    April 27, 2006 at 7:26 pm

    I agree that this is a gripe about the VB team’s selection of keywords or implementation of logical and bitwise comparisons, but I do not think it has zero technical value. It clearly shows a difference between VB and C#, which can be part of the decision process of which language to use. Another good example of language difference being a decision factor is VB’s ability to have Optional parameters, I would choose VB.NET for VSTO (Visual Studio Tools for Office) 100 times out of 100 over C#, just so I don’t have to write Type.Missing for the hundreds of parameters for some of the Word and Excel methods. Okay hundreds is a stretch, but some have ALOT of parameters.
    The article would have been of no technical value had it said something like “The sky is blue…”

  2. heck says:
    April 27, 2006 at 4:35 pm

    In any case, the article doesn’t add any insight of technical value, rather it simply complains about VB. Whether or not another language is better is irrelevent. I have to agree with FoxedUp that this article lowers the quality of CodeBetter. The only value it provides is if a developer was previously unaware of the existence of AndAlso/OrElse, or perhaps knew the synatx in C# but not in VB.

  3. Karl Anderson says:
    April 26, 2006 at 2:32 pm

    The comment Karl (sorry my name is Karl as well) made about ALWAYS using OrElse and AndAlso has one caveat, this is assuming that you are doing BOOLEAN comparisons. If you have a flags enumeration (hex values) and try and do an OrElse or AndAlso, then you are going to get some very unexpected behavior. I think this should have been a compelling enough reason for the VB team to consider the compiler to not let you use Or and And with logical (Boolean) comparisons, but force you to use the OrElse and AndAlso statements. Just my two cents.

    Karl

  4. shebert says:
    April 26, 2006 at 11:30 am

    Where did I say C# is better than VB? I’m simply saying that the selection of the implementations for And and Or are lousy.

    btw: I don’t think C++ is that great of a language – if you want to see a language riddled with unintended side-effects in the name of “efficiency”, c++ is it. The And/Or implementations are far less aggregious than the New->Malloc connection in C++

    See ->http://codebetter.com/blogs/steve.hebert/archive/2006/03/03/139700.aspx

    If this and not that then nothing.

    That about sums it up for the language.

  7. karl says:
    April 25, 2006 at 11:18 pm

    I don’t mind AndAlso and OrElse, though I agree it’s somewhat funny.

    For anyone interested,Paul Vick went over the history of these a while ago:
    http://www.panopticoncentral.net/archive/2003/08/18/179.aspx

    I must say, you should ALWAYS use AndAlso or OrElse in your conditional statements. There’s never a good reason to use and and/or else. Using and/or can lead to subtle (ie, dangerous) bugs and performs worse!

  8. shebert says:
    April 25, 2006 at 10:17 pm

    No disagreement here – && and || aren’t very readable. But they function as AND and OR operators taught in every CS course in the world.

    Given that they changed so many other things from VB6, I wish they would have pulled the trigger on this one too.

    The problem with this kind of variation is that while it may work for someone trained ground-up in VB, someone making a jump from other languages will get bit by this one.

    OK, I think it is silly. But despite being mostly on C# ‘s side, I have to admit that && and || are a bit silly too. At least we don;t have to use -> as in my old C++ days
